story.text: Here’s every single rated tourist attraction in the United States, represented by a blue dot. That’s 80,197 “things to do,” according to Trip Advisor.

And we really mean everything: from the Seven Stars Alpaca Ranch (the #1 thing to do in Coeur D’Alene) to the Heaviest Corner on Earth (rating: 3.46; Birmingham, AL). But let’s take a look at New York City.

What’s more closely associated with New York than visiting the Statue of Liberty, or a blissful stroll through Times Square? As it happens, many New Yorkers would beg to differ — the vast majority have never made a pilgrimage to Lady Liberty, and Times Square is often considered a no-go zone.

This divergence between the popular conception of New York City and the way that locals view it is emblematic of a kind of tourist/local divide. Eric Fisher documented this a decade ago: tourists seek out the famous destinations, while locals have their own, lesser-known but much-beloved, corners of the city. Thus, I began to wonder: what would a travel guide curated solely by those who lived within driving distance of a location look like? To give us a sense of this, let’s remove the sites whose reviews came from a majority (60%+) of visitors who live more than 60 miles/100km away. Let’s also size them by the total number of visitors.

So long, Times Square. But let’s face it, no one wants to go to the worst-reviewed park in New York City (unless you’re these folks). Let’s color code the attractions from lowest low (3 or below) to highest (5) rated.

Many of the better-known destinations — whether Central Park or the Empire State building fade away. Instead, often-overlooked spots like the Hauser & Wirth gallery in Chelsea, and green spaces like the 6BC Botanical Gardens in the East Village come to the forefront.
